name: USA Alphabetically - Part W Quiz | USA | 10 Questions

questions.text: Incorporated in 1845, which city on the Cedar River was originally called Prairie Rapids Crossing?
questions.explanation:
Waterloo.

	Waterloo, Iowa is the county seat of Black Hawk County. The city's economy, traditionally based on agriculture, became more diversified after the agricultural recession of the 1980s.

questions.text: "Twin City" and "Camel City" are nicknames sometimes applied to which of these cities?
questions.explanation:
Winston-Salem.

	Winston-Salem, North Carolina was originally two separate towns.  Salem, founded in 1753, and Winston, founded in 1849, amalgamated in 1889. Wake Forest University was established in a small town of that name in 1834, but moved to Winston-Salem in 1946.

questions.text: Where is the United States Military Academy located?
questions.explanation:
West Point.

	Located on the banks of the Hudson River, in New York State, West Point has been home to the US Military Academy since 1802. A military garrison was first constructed on the site in 1778. A branch of the US Mint is also located at West Point.

questions.text: Which city was founded in 1638 as Fort Christina as the headquarters of New Sweden?
questions.explanation:
Wilmington.

	The largest city in Delaware, Wilmington is located on the Delaware River, a few miles southwest of Philadelphia. The British took over the area in 1644 and renamed the city after a former British Prime Minister, Lord Wilmington. Wilmington is home to a number of major credit card companies.

questions.text: Which city on the Arkansas River was incorporated in 1870 and named after a local Native American tribe?
questions.explanation:
Wichita.

	Wichita is the county seat of Sedgwick County, Kansas. The city's position on the Chisholm Trail made it an important cattle-driving destination in the 19th century.  In the early 20th century, aircraft manufacture became the biggest industry in the city, with several manufacturers based there. This led to the city being nicknamed "The Air Capital of the World".

questions.text: Which city is the permanent home of the Little League World Series?
questions.explanation:
Williamsport.

	Incorporated in 1806, Williamsport is located in Lycoming County, Pennsylvania, on the banks of the Susquehanna River. The Little League World Series is held there each August.

questions.text: Baylor University, the Dr Pepper Museum, and the Texas Ranger Hall of Fame and Museum can all be found in which city?
questions.explanation:
Waco.

	The county seat of McLennan County in Texas, Waco is named after a Native American tribe which lived in the area. Dr Pepper was invented in the city in 1885. The following year, Baylor University relocated to Waco from its original home of Independence.

questions.text: The Smithsonian Institution is located in which city?
questions.explanation:
Washington, D.C.

	The capital city of the USA, Washington, D.C, was founded on July 16th, 1790. Named after the first President of the USA, George Washington, the city was specifically designed as the nation's capital. The Smithsonian Institution includes numerous museums and art galleries, including the National Museum of American History and the National Portrait Gallery.

questions.text: Purdue University is located in which city?
questions.explanation:
West Lafayette.

	West Lafayette is a city in Indiana, on the opposite bank of the Wabash River from Lafayette. It was founded in 1888 by the merger of the towns of Chauncey, Kingston, and Oakwood. Purdue University is named after local industrialist, John Purdue.

questions.text: Which city was founded under the name of Middle Plantation in 1632, and is home to the College of William & Mary?
questions.explanation:
Williamsburg.

	Williamsburg replaced Jamestown as capital of the Virginia Colony in 1698, and retained this status until 1780. Much of the early settlement has been restored as Colonial Williamsburg, a major tourist attraction in the early 21st century.
